awd_titl_txt: Exploring New Frontiers in Spin-1 Dynamics, Geometry and Metrology
awd_abstract_narration:
This research will explore the behavior of small clouds of atoms cooled close to absolute zero and interacting primarily via their magnetic spins. This research will advance the fundamental understanding of the quantum dynamics of many-particle systems, which is an area of fundamental physics important to condensed matter physics, nuclear physics and astrophysics.  In addition, this research will inform important technological applications including precision sensors for navigation and magnetometry, atomic clocks and emerging quantum technologies including quantum information and communication.

The experiments use small clouds of rubidium-87 atoms that are cooled to temperatures less than 100 nanoKelvin above absolute zero and confined with laser beams in an evacuated chamber. At these low temperatures, the atoms form a Bose-Einstein condensate, which is a unique quantum phase of matter. This project focuses on the dynamics of the intrinsic spin of the atoms, which is a fundamental component of quantum magnetism.  The experiments feature precise control of the quantum states of the atoms using external fields, a well-characterized dynamics, a quantum phase transition, and low-noise tomographic quantum state measurement capabilities. These tools will permit studies of finite size effects of a quantum phase transition in the neighborhood of the critical point, demonstration of new methods of creating and controlling highly entangled states of the ensembles, and investigation of new non-Abelian geometrical phases unique to spin-1 systems.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This research explored new techniques for studying quantum phenomena using laser-cooled and laser-trapped atoms. The experiments used rubidium atoms isolated in a high vacuum chamber that were laser-cooled to within a millionth of a degree above absolute zero temperature. At these low temperatures, the random motion of the gaseous atoms almost comes to a complete standstill, and allows the atoms to be trapped at the focus of a high power laser beam.  These atoms are further cooled in this laser trap until they undergo a phase transition to a quantum state of matter known as a Bose-Einstein condensate (BEC) for which the state of motion of all of the atoms (ensembles of 10s of thousand) becomes identical while still remaining a gas. This so-called quantum gas provides a powerful tool to explore quantum mechanics with exquisite accuracy and precision.      


Our research in this project focused on studying the internal degrees of freedom of this quantum gas that arises from the intrinsic spin of the rubidium atoms. Each rubidium atom has a magnetic moment arising from the interplay of the electrons, protons and neutrons and hence exhibits magnetic behavior similar to common bar magnets. Just as different materials have different magnetic behavior, so is the case for atomic condensates. The magnetic effects are indeed very weak in this case, but the ultra low temperatures and collective coherence provided by the quantum gas allow the ability to perform high precision studies of the interaction of the atomic magnets. 


The primary outcomes of this work was 1) the development of new techniques to control the atomic spins using external magnetic fields provided by carefully tailored microwave pulses and 2) the development of new methods to increase the precision of the measurement of the spins using quantum entanglement.  


In addition to advancing the frontiers of quantum science, this research provided training to students in experimental techniques of ultracold atoms. This research also provided training in a broad array of technologies including optics, lasers, electronics, ultra-high vacuum, imaging, sensing and control. Additionally, the students present their results at national and international meetings and prepare manuscripts for publication in peer reviewed journals.  The results of our research are disseminated through journal articles, presentations at seminars and conferences and through our webpage. In future work, we plan to continue to explore the novel quantum control techniques and exploration of non-classical entangled states created in our condensates.
